Isowitz,

Here you can find an example junit report that contains both the =

results of your tests, and the information that is logged during the 
test=
s: 
http://junitpdfreport.sourceforge.net/tests/

Regards, Jan

--- In juni=
t@yahoogroups.com, "isowitz" <isowitz@...> wrote:
>
> Thank you for your an=
swer. 
> Am I right? JUnit generates his own reports for failed tests? How =

can 
> I catch them? Or what do you mean with reports for aggregate 
> inf=
ormation? Are that reports different from the logging I generate 
> with eg=
 log4j?
> 
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, didoss@ wrote:
> >
> > That soun=
ds like two different things:
> > 
> > The logging, whether through log4j (=
which I also like) or 
something 
> else, will provide debugging informatio=
n to you.
> > 
> > The reports are useful for aggregate information (like h=
ow many 
> failures and errors for X number of tests for the whole product =

> suite, or whatever scope you run) and information about tests 
passed 
>=
 and failed (errors and failures).
> > 
> > For the tests that failed, you =
might use the information from the 
> report (which will give you informati=
on around the issue - stack 
> trace or failure information) or information=
 from the log files 
> (information for the entire run - you might be able =
to see the 
> progression of state that led to the failure/error) to troubl=
eshoot 
> and fix.
> > 
> > I generally take the reports, or the result of =
an individual run, 
> as my starting point, and then only look at the loggi=
ng for the 
ones 
> that failed in some way.  If I have written my asserts =
well, I 
> usually don't even need to look at the logging, because I will k=
now 
> exactly what went wrong.
> > 
> > Hope this helps and good luck on t=
he migration.
> > 
> > 
> > Dianne
